sanskrit: धर्म एव हतो हन्ति, धर्मो रक्षति रक्षितः।
translation: Dharma, when destroyed, destroys; Dharma, when protected, protects. (Mahabharata 12.15.24)
Indeed, no one can remain without action even for a moment. (Mahabharata 6.29.21)
It is better to die performing one’s own duty than to follow another’s path, which is full of fear. (Mahabharata 6.29.34)
The Earth belongs to the brave. (Mahabharata 5.141.17)
Arise, O Bharata, determined to fight and fulfill your duty. (Mahabharata 6.29.33)
One who lacks strength is easily defeated. (Mahabharata 12.36.12)

sanskrit: युद्धे च क्रियते कर्म यदवश्यं करिष्यति।
translation: In battle, one must perform their duty without hesitation. (Mahabharata 6.11.21)

sanskrit: न सा सभा यत्र न सन्ति वृद्धाः।
translation: That is not an assembly where there are no wise elders. (Mahabharata 5.37.15)
Patience, forgiveness, self-control, honesty, purity, and mastery over the senses are the virtues of the wise. (Mahabharata 12.60.7)

sanskrit: सूर्यः स्वयं प्रकाशते न तस्य प्रकाशः अन्यः।
translation: The Sun shines by itself and does not depend on another light. (Mahabharata 12.147.4)

sanskrit: प्रयत्नं हि पुरुषेण कर्तव्यं श्रेयसे सदा।
translation: A person must always make efforts for a better future. (Mahabharata 12.168.8)
Through strength, one gains valor; through strength, one attains victory. (Mahabharata 5.39.21)

sanskrit: विजयाय कृतो यत्नः कार्यः स्वेनैव तेजसा।
translation: Victory is achieved through one's own effort and energy. (Mahabharata 5.39.25)

sanskrit: सत्यं हि परमं ब्रह्म सत्याद् धर्मः प्रवर्तते।
translation: Truth is the ultimate reality; righteousness arises from truth. (Mahabharata 12.174.17)

sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते।
translation: Nothing is as purifying as knowledge in this world. (Mahabharata 12.196.10)

sanskrit: विद्या नाम नरस्य रूपमधिकं प्रच्छन्नगुप्तं धनम्।
translation: Knowledge is the greatest adornment of a person; it is a hidden treasure. (Mahabharata 12.292.24)

sanskrit: सन्तोषः परमं द्रव्यं सन्तोषः परमं सुखम्।
translation: Contentment is the greatest wealth, and satisfaction is the highest happiness. (Mahabharata 12.320.19)

sanskrit: न हिंसा परमं धर्मं श्रुत्वा धर्मं तथाविधम्।
translation: Non-violence is the highest Dharma; live righteously and let others live. (Mahabharata 12.254.27)

sanskrit: कामं क्रोधं च लोभं च मानं च परिगृह्य च।
translation: Control desire, anger, greed, and pride, for they lead to downfall. (Mahabharata 12.177.21)

sanskrit: कृतज्ञता च पुण्यानि कुरुते ह्यपराणि च।
translation: Gratitude begets virtues and leads to greater goodness. (Mahabharata 12.138.7)
If the mind is disciplined, nothing is impossible. (Mahabharata 12.168.9)
No one knows everything, nor is there anyone who knows nothing. (Mahabharata 12.174.19)
Where there is Dharma, there is victory. (Mahabharata 6.19.38)
One who does good, O dear Arjuna, is never overcome by evil. (Mahabharata 6.40)
You have the right to perform your duty, but never to the fruits thereof. (Bhagavad Gita 2.47)

sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि संगं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय।
translation: Perform your duty while being steadfast in yoga, O Arjuna, abandoning attachment. (Bhagavad Gita 2.48)
Indeed, no one can remain without action even for a moment. (Bhagavad Gita 3.5)
Be steadfast in pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat. (Bhagavad Gita 2.38)
One who is free from attachment, ego, and filled with perseverance and enthusiasm attains success. (Bhagavad Gita 18.26)
One whose intellect is illuminated by the fire of self-discipline attains true wisdom. (Bhagavad Gita 4.19)

sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते।
translation: Nothing is as purifying as knowledge in this world. (Bhagavad Gita 4.38)

sanskrit: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः।
translation: The unreal has no existence, and the real never ceases to be. (Bhagavad Gita 2.16)
Therefore, cut the ignorance in your heart with the sword of wisdom. (Bhagavad Gita 4.42)
It is better to perform one's own duty imperfectly than to master another’s duty. (Bhagavad Gita 18.47)
Lift yourself by your own efforts; do not degrade yourself. (Bhagavad Gita 6.5)
One who does good, O dear Arjuna, is never overcome by evil. (Bhagavad Gita 6.40)
Dedicate all actions to Me with your mind fixed on the Supreme. (Bhagavad Gita 3.30)
Those who worship Me with unwavering focus, I ensure their welfare. (Bhagavad Gita 9.22)
He who abandons all desires and moves free from attachment achieves peace. (Bhagavad Gita 2.71)
Some perceive the self within through meditation. (Bhagavad Gita 13.25)
Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, you can cross over sin by the boat of wisdom. (Bhagavad Gita 4.36)
Abandon all varieties of religion and just surrender unto Me. (Bhagavad Gita 18.66)

sanskrit: न जयत्यसहायोऽपि सत्यं वदति यो नरः।
translation: A person who speaks the truth always attains victory, even if alone. (Bhagavad Gita 4.39)
Therefore, always perform your duty without attachment. (Bhagavad Gita 3.19)

sanskrit: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन।
translation: O Arjuna, I have nothing to gain in the three worlds, yet I engage in action. (Bhagavad Gita 3.22)
Just as fire reduces wood to ashes, so does wisdom burn all karma to ashes. (Bhagavad Gita 4.37)
One should earn wealth righteously and share it according to one's capacity. (Bhagavad Gita 16.1)

translation: Ignorance is the greatest enemy, while knowledge is the greatest strength. (Mahabharata 5.38.29)
